comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Donnybrook Rugby Ground is jointly held by Bective and Old Wesley Rugby Clubs but that's only a minor factor.  Bective were always one of the great Dublin rugby clubs and it is sad that they are not at the top tier today!  Great detective work by all in a very short space of time.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: 15th August 1927 is my bet! Any other ideas?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Religious War is probably the Cristero War, and a quick search of the Irish Times archive suggests 30th July 1926, Page 7: MEXICO'S WAR ON RELIGION. The girls seem to be in summer dresses, and the men are not wearing overcoats, so that lines up.

comment.author: 60765183@N08
comment._content: On "Confesserie": This must be a variant of confiserie (sweet shop in French); it could be  German or Alsatian.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: There was some talk about the Rugby Ground earlier. This was the original location for the famous (infamous) Donnybrook Fair. OSI map and see History Oxford Dictionary of Modern Slang: Donnybrook, noun A scene of uproar and disorder; a riotous or uproarious meeting; a heated argument. (1852 —) . Economist Imagine the Donnybrook there would be in France or Italy (1966).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Any idea when that space became rugby territory?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I think so too! And I searched the Irish Times over a two year period, and that was the only time the war in Mexico was reported with that exact headline! Fantastic to go from unsure location and no date at all on Friday morning to a secure location and date...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] Bective rangers moved there in 1910.  It may have been a rugby ground before then but from then on it remained one.  I always loved the pitch there, it was a pleasure to play on and very intimate atmosphere for matches I would love to have seen it upgraded but the RDS is doing well for Leinster these days.  Incidentally congratulations to Leinster and Ulster on making 2012 an all Ireland European cup final.  Look out Twickenham, you've never seen passion on this scale chariots or none;-)

comment.author: 41623432@N05
comment._content: the patisserie in the 60s /70s was owned by a miss van knockerout[sp]it sold fancy meats in the delicatessen section,along with fine wines etc..jim o brien [of o brien wines ]worked there,and now holds this one along with a few more.its a great photo,the garda station was built after the street widening c 1931.and st marys graveyard entrance, etc was also pushed back a few yards..

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41623432@N05] Thanks. Lovely to hear more recent information about any of our photos, and that's some continuity for Jim O'Brien.
